posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I’ve got the opportunity to build a full field at a long term facility.  My question: does anyone happen to have sensible prints for a wood full field?

posts.name: Arnan Srivastava
posts.cooked:
This page hosts links to a variety of ways FIRST Robotics Competition® community can experience the FIRST Robotics Competition playing field. FIRST is grateful to the supporters that created these assets.

Not full wood but for the most part

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
A full wooden field would include sides and driver stations. HQ’s “Team Element” drawings don’t… which is why the question is being asked.

@Andy_Baker didn’t you guys have a wooden field drawing at one point, before you sold metal fields? I seem to remember a group in my area building same and it lasting for quite a while. Mostly 2x4s, with plywood (and chicken wire) on the driver stations. Plywood entry gates needed a lot of maintenance, for various reasons.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: whatever you do, make sure you’re not leaving anything sticking out of the walls to tear your bumpers. Someone left a sheared screw in our wall which put a 12" cut in 1 day old bumpers. Alro sells 1/16" ABS sheets very cheaply if you’re making a decent sized plastics order. I’d recommend covering at least the bottom 8" of your walls with plastic to avoid splinters and extra wear on your bumpers.

posts.name: Doug Frisk
posts.cooked:
As you are building this. Please think in terms of the day you have to store it. Make sure component pieces are small enough for two people to carry them and they are designed to stack or nest in storage. Once you have built it, you want to be able to move it or store it when the school decides they have another use for the space they are letting you use.

It’s $28,000 these days, but the AndyMark field is worth it if you are going to have to tear down and rebuild even a few times.

posts.name: Carlos Reckner
posts.cooked:
I have a pdf file of a FIRST wooden field layout that we used to rebuild our field several years ago.

It includes driver stations that can be moved and reconfigured as required. It has served us and teams that visit us quite well.

I had found it here quite a while ago. I tried to update/edit this post to attach the pdf file, but it does not seem to take the pdf in properly. Let me know if you are interested and I can see about how I can get the file to you.

(406.0 KB)

link_counts.title: Budget field walls that can be easily set up and torn down

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
Do you mean this one? https://files.andymark.com/2008- FRC -wooden-field-border.pdf

We built it last year, for around $2000. Still a great investment! Be sure to read through the design carefully, I recall there were a few oddities with the two variants (straight or angled corner walls). We intend to replace the triangle connector joints with steel tubing and bolts after seeing Mean Machine’s upgrade this year.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
That looks familiar!

The unit built in 2008 (Come to think of it… actually might have been a season or so earlier?) was still in service as of 2019, with some tweaks and repairs. Don’t recall exactly what happened to it; it may still be kicking around Orange County (CA, not FL or NY) to this day.

The issue we often had was the gate close-and-latch system, while quick, tended to have warped plywood. (Partly because we didn’t do the whole pivot and hold on both sides shown in the drawing…) That’s a place that if I were doing it again, I’d add some beef and possibly some better latching. Other than that, it’s tough enough to handle quite some abuse.
